titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Hunein F. Maassab papers, 1951-2002
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Kyle Conner and Christie S. Peterson in July 2006

did.abstract: Epidemiologist Hunein F. "John" Maassab was a researcher and professor at the University of Michigan School of Public Health. Maassab's papers, 1951-2002, comprise correspondence, publications, and laboratory documents related to his research into cold adapted live virus vaccines for influenza, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and other viruses and development of the "flu mist" vaccine. The collection also includes materials for several upper courses Maassab taught in the Department of Epidemiology.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were received from Dr. Maassabâ€™s office in the School of Public Health (Donor No. 9366) in 2003.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The Maassab papers are open for research use with the exception of some files that may contain personally identifiable information on patients or participants in various experiments and trials. These files are closed in accord with applicable law and university policy on patient/client records.

The Maassab papers includes restricted material in the following categories:
Patient/Client Records -- Boxes 15-17, 20, 21, 28-30

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Hunein F. Maassab papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Hunein F. "John" Maassab was born in Damascus, Syria in 1928. He emigrated to the United States in 1947, became a permanent resident in 1955, and gained United States citizenship in 1960. He and his wife, Hilda Zahka, had twin sons, Sammy and Fred, born in 1959.

Maassab graduated from Greek Orthodox High School in Damascus in 1945. After moving to the United States, Maassab earned a B.A. in Biology and an M.A. in Physiology and Pharmacology from the University of Missouri. Maassab then moved to the University of Michigan, where he earned his M.Ph. in 1954 and his Ph.D. in Epidemiological Sciences in 1956. Dr. Maassab remained in the Department of Epidemiology in the University of Michigan School of Public Health, where he became a professor in 1960.

Inspired by the work of Dr. Thomas Francis and other pioneers in the Department of Epidemiology, Maassab has dedicated his career to developing cold-adapted live virus vaccines for influenza, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), and other viruses. This work culminated in the licensing of Maassab's patented "Master Strain" for creating live virus vaccines against Influenza A and B to Aviron, a pharmaceutical company that intended to market the vaccine as "Flu Mist," a nasal-spray alternative to traditional vaccine injections.

scopecontent.p: The Hunein F. "John" Maassab papers, 1951-2002, consist of correspondence, publications, and laboratory documents related to his research into cold adapted live virus vaccines for influenza, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and other viruses and development of the "flu mist" vaccine. The collection also includes materials for several upper courses Maassab taught in the Department of Epidemiology. are divided into six series: General (1967-2002), Teaching (1975-2000), Correspondence (1960-2000), Topical Files (1955-2001), Publications (1954-1999), and Research (1951-1999).

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Epidemiology.
Influenza.
Medicine--Michigan.
Public health--United States.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Public Health.

scopecontent.p: General, 1967-2002 comprises primarily biographical and background information about Maassab. It also contains one folder of indexes to reference files. These indexes were originally stored along with the reference materials listed on them in plastic magazine holders in Maassab's office. During processing of the collection, the articles were not retained but the indices were kept as evidence of the extensive reference files.

did.unittitle: Lists of Abbreviations and Acronyms undated

scopecontent.p: Teaching, 1975-2000 comprises materials from several courses Maassab taught in the Department of Epidemiology in the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. When it was accessioned, the entire collection had little original order. This was particularly true of the teaching materials, which were stored in letterboxes with no overall organizational scheme or indication of their purpose. As a result, some materials in this series, particularly the figures, notes and overheads at the end of the series, may have originally been used for presentations at professional conferences or other activities other than teaching.

did.unittitle: Epidemiology 519-Introduction to Principles and Methods of Molecular Epidemiology 2000-2001
Definition and Classification of Viruses undated
Epidemiology 594-Genetic Analysis of Cell and Virus Functions 1972
Miscellaneous Figures, Abstracts and Summaries undated
Miscellaneous Notes, Images and Charts undated
Thesis Committees 1989-2000 (includes a 3.5" floppy disc, WordPerfect files)

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, 1960-2000 is arranged chronologically. When it was accessioned, the papers contained a small series of chronological correspondence files from the 1990s. During processing, these chronological files were retained and expanded to include miscellaneous correspondence that was found dispersed throughout the collection.

Topical Files, 1955-2001 comprises existing background and subject files that were scattered throughout the collection when it was accessioned, along with several files that were created during processing, such as when a significant amount of topically related material was found that did not fit logically into another series. These topical files contain a great deal of correspondence, along with other miscellaneous documents, such as Maassab's graduate school records.

scopecontent.p: Publications, 1954-1999 comprises a nearly complete set of Maassab's professional publications and non-published professional writings, arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Research, 1951-1999 comprises records related to Maassab's research in the Department of Epidemiology at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. The first two subseries, Budgets and Proposals, Contracts and Reports, relate to the funding and administration of his research. Laboratory Procedures includes notebooks and documents used in Maassab's laboratory to teach and remind researchers of standard procedures, recipes and protocols. The subseries Virus Inventories and Passage Histories comprises lists of viruses stored, used and shared by the laboratory, along with histories of several of the more important viruses. Laboratory Notebooks and Data is the largest subseries, and comprises numerous series of binders and notebooks that record Maassab's research. Most of this subseries was originally stored in three-ring binders. During processing, the binders were removed, but their labels were recorded on the folders to which the materials were transferred, and whenever possible, the binder labels were removed and placed in the front of the folders. A number of boxes in this subseries are restricted from researcher use because they contain documents, usually related to sera collection or vaccine trials, that link individual names with sensitive medical information.
